## Introduction
Marlon Brando was an American actor and film director who is widely regarded as one of the greatest actors in the history of American cinema. He rose to prominence in the 1950s with his powerful performances in films such as "A Streetcar Named Desire" and "On the Waterfront." Brando's acting style and method approach revolutionized the craft of acting and left a lasting impact on the film industry.

## Key Terms
- Method Acting: A technique in which actors draw upon their own emotions and experiences to portray a character realistically.
- The Stanislavski System: An acting method developed by Russian actor and director Konstantin Stanislavski, which focuses on emotional truth and psychological realism in performance.

## Detailed Life
Marlon Brando was born on April 3, 1924, in Omaha, Nebraska. He grew up in a middle-class family and had a troubled childhood. Brando's parents divorced when he was young, and he had a strained relationship with his father. Despite his difficult upbringing, Brando developed an early interest in acting and attended the Dramatic Workshop at The New School in New York City.

Brando made his Broadway debut in 1944 in the play "I Remember Mama." He gained critical acclaim for his performance and soon caught the attention of Hollywood. In 1950, he made his film debut in "The Men," playing a paralyzed war veteran. His raw and emotionally charged portrayal garnered widespread praise.

Throughout his career, Brando became known for his intense and immersive acting style. He embraced the method acting approach, studying under Stella Adler and later working with Lee Strasberg at the Actors Studio. This approach allowed him to bring a sense of authenticity and realism to his characters.

Some of Brando's most notable films include "A Streetcar Named Desire" (1951), "On the Waterfront" (1954), and "The Godfather" (1972). He won two Academy Awards for Best Actor, one for "On the Waterfront" and another for "The Godfather." Brando's performances were often characterized by his ability to convey a wide range of emotions and his physicality on screen.

## Little Known Facts
- Marlon Brando was offered the role of Superman's father, Jor-El, in the 1978 film "Superman," but he turned it down.
- Brando was known for his eccentric behavior and unconventional acting methods, often improvising and challenging directors.

## Examples
One of the most iconic examples of Marlon Brando's acting prowess is his portrayal of Stanley Kowalski in the film adaptation of "A Streetcar Named Desire." His performance as the brutish and volatile character captivated audiences and earned him an Academy Award nomination.

In "On the Waterfront," Brando played the role of Terry Malloy, an ex-prizefighter turned longshoreman. His portrayal of the conflicted and morally torn character showcased his ability to convey complex emotions and earned him his first Academy Award for Best Actor.

## Historical Context
Marlon Brando's career flourished during the post-World War II era, a time of social and cultural change in America. His performances often reflected the struggles and aspirations of the working class, resonating with audiences who were grappling with the aftermath of war and the changing dynamics of society.

Brando's acting style also emerged in the context of the rise of method acting and the influence of the Stanislavski System. This approach to acting emphasized psychological realism and emotional truth, challenging traditional notions of performance and paving the way for a new generation of actors.

## Questions and Answers
1. Q: What impact did Marlon Brando have on the film industry?
   - A: Marlon Brando revolutionized acting with his method approach, bringing a new level of realism and emotional depth to performances. His influence can be seen in the work of countless actors who followed in his footsteps.

2. Q: What are some of Marlon Brando's most famous films?
   - A: Some of Marlon Brando's most famous films include "A Streetcar Named Desire," "On the Waterfront," and "The Godfather."

## Family-Friends
Marlon Brando had three wives throughout his life: Anna Kashfi, Movita Castaneda, and Tarita Teriipaia. He had a total of 11 children, including his son Christian Brando, who also pursued a career in acting.

Brando had friendships with several notable individuals in the entertainment industry, including actors James Dean and Montgomery Clift.

## Quotes
- "Acting is the expression of a neurotic impulse. It's a bum's life. Quitting acting, that's the sign of maturity." 
- "An actor is at most a poet and at least an entertainer."
- "The only thing an actor owes his public is not to bore them."
